qas.question: What did an alternate version of the incandescent lamp substitute for a wire filament?

answers.text: an arc struck on a spherical bead electrode

qas.question: What was a common application for this type of bulb?
When was this style of lamp developed?
What displaced this style of lamp?
What type of lamp used a hot wire filament?

plausible_answers.text: A variation of the incandescent lamp

qas.question: What type of lamp did not use an arc struck on a spherical bead electrode?
What was not a common use for this type of bulb?
What type of lamp typically ran on relatively high voltages?
What type of lamp provided a low concentrated light that was harder to operate?

context: <b4_0><b5_0>A variation of the incandescent<b4_0/> lamp<b5_0/> did not use a hot wire filament, but instead used <a0_0>an arc struck on a spherical bead electrode<a0_0/> to produce heat. The electrode then became incandescent, with the arc contributing little to the light produced. Such lamps were used for projection or illumination for <a1_0><b6_0>scientific instruments such as microscopes<b6_0/><a1_0/>. These <b7_0>arc<b7_0/> lamps ran on relatively low voltages and incorporated tungsten filaments to start ionization within the envelope. They provided the intense concentrated light of an <b8_0>arc<b8_0/> lamp but were easier to operate. Developed around <a2_0>1915<a2_0/>, these lamps were displaced by <a3_0>mercury and xenon arc lamps<a3_0/>.
